In other words, education, during this period
should concentrate on reinforcing those ex¬
periences which help children understand the
learning process itself. Basically, it is the
"learning how to learn" phase of education. It
is in this phase of life that the most significant
habits are formed, habits which can make the dif¬
ference between success or failure in education.
Those youngsters who are failing by the 5th or 6th
grade, it is almost inevitable that they will be¬
come the drop-outs of the 7th or 8th grade. It is
not difficult to relate successfully to these
children, but every attempt should be made to do
more than relate, we must rekindle their aspirations
to succeed. For the youngster who has made it through
the 8th grade, and then drops out of school, the
problems are more complicated. A large number of
children who "just" made it rarely believe that they
had come so far on their own efforts. Often the
teacher is to blame for this feeling in children
because many play the role of "magnanimous benefactor."
So deeply traumatic is this experience for the child
that he may never recuperate, never feel worthy, or
more significantly, never feel that it was his effort
